user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_shmem_open_generic:
```c
int metal_shmem_open_generic(const char *name, size_t size,
			     struct metal_io_region **result)
{
	struct metal_generic_shmem *shmem;
	struct metal_list *node;

	metal_list_for_each(&_metal.common.generic_shmem_list, node) {
		shmem = metal_container_of(node, struct metal_generic_shmem, node);
		if (strcmp(shmem->name, name) != 0)
			continue;
		if (size <= metal_io_region_size(&shmem->io)) {
			*result = &shmem->io;
			return 0;
		}
	}

	return -ENOENT;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_shmem_open_generic:
struct metal_io_region {
	void			*virt;      /**< base virtual address */
	const metal_phys_addr_t	*physmap;   /**< table of base physical address
						 of each of the pages in the I/O
						 region */
	size_t			size;       /**< size of the I/O region */
	unsigned long		page_shift; /**< page shift of I/O region */
	metal_phys_addr_t	page_mask;  /**< page mask of I/O region */
	unsigned int		mem_flags;  /**< memory attribute of the
						 I/O region */
	struct metal_io_ops	ops;        /**< I/O region operations */
}
...
struct metal_generic_shmem {
	const char		*name;
	struct metal_io_region	io;
	struct metal_list	node;
}
...
struct metal_list {
	struct metal_list *next, *prev;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
int metal_shmem_open_generic(const char *name, size_t size,
			     struct metal_io_region **result)
explanation:
I did not include the following fragments because they do not indicate a potential Rule 8.13 issue: 
- const char *name (already const-qualified).
- const metal_phys_addr_t *physmap (already const-qualified).
- Non-pointer members of struct metal_io_region (size, page_shift, page_mask, mem_flags) and the ops member — Rule 8.13 applies to pointer types only.
- struct metal_generic_shmem { ... struct metal_list node; } — node is an embedded struct (not a pointer), so Rule 8.13 is not applicable.
- Any comment lines or macro invocations (e.g., metal_list_for_each) were not flagged because they are not pointer declarations that could be const-qualified themselves.  
The listed fragments are those pointer declarations/uses in the provided code that could plausibly be const-qualified and therefore warrant investigation for compliance with MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13.
